Let $M$ be a set. The Cartesian product of $M$ with itself, denoted as $M \times M$, is the set of all ordered pairs of elements from $M$.
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.

An element a of a ring R is called a zero divisor if there exists an element b in R - {0} such that ab=0 or ba=0. Fields and skew fields do not admit any zero divisors, except for 0, the trivial zero divisor.
An ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ in a ring $R$ is finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators.

An integral domain $R$ is called a Euclidean domain if it admits a map $\delta: R-\{0\} \longrightarrow \mathbb{N}$ making possible Euclidean division in $R$ in the following sense: Given elements $f, g \in R, g \neq 0$, there are elements $q, r \in R$ such that $f=q g+r$, where $\delta(r)<\delta(g)$ or $r=0$.
Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.

Kronecker's construction defines an extension field by taking the quotient of the polynomial ring of the base field by the ideal generated by an irreducible polynomial. The residue class of the indeterminate in this quotient field is a zero of the polynomial, allowing the successive adjoining of zeros of polynomials to the base field.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is finite if $B$ is a finite $A$-module under $\varphi$. This is also referred to as $B$ being finite over $A$ or, if $\varphi$ is an inclusion homomorphism, that the extension $A \hookrightarrow B$ is finite.
Splitting Field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield

A field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is a splitting field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ if the polynomial factorizes into linear factors in $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$. This implies that $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ contains all zeros of $X^q-X$.

A group $G$ is called solvable if there exists a chain of subgroups $G_{0} \\supsetneq G_{1} \\supsetneq \\ldots \\supsetneq G_{r}=\\{1\\}$ such that each $G_{i+1}$ is a normal subgroup of $G_{i}$ and the residue class group $G_{i} / G_{i+1}$ is abelian.
The kernel of \( f \) is defined as:\[\mathrm{Ker}(f) = \{ a \in A \mid f(a) = 0 \} and is hence a subset of the Domain A.\]

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of a cyclic group involves the concept of a group, as it is defined as a group generated by a single element.
The definition of a zero divisor involves the concept of a ring, as it is defined as an element of a ring that satisfies a certain property.
The definition of a finitely generated ideal involves the concept of an ideal and a ring, as it is defined as an ideal in a ring that has a finite system of generators.
The definition of a Euclidean domain involves the concept of an integral domain, which is a type of ring.
The definition of an A-homomorphism involves the concept of A-modules, which are generalizations of vector spaces.

The definition of Kronecker's construction involves the concept of a polynomial ring and an ideal, as it defines an extension field by taking the quotient of the polynomial ring by the ideal generated by an irreducible polynomial.
The definition of a finite ring homomorphism involves the concept of a ring homomorphism and a module, as it is defined as a ring homomorphism where the codomain is a finite module over the domain.
The definition of the splitting field of a polynomial involves the concept of a field and a polynomial, as it is defined as a field in which the polynomial factorizes into linear factors.
The definition of a solvable group involves the concept of a group, as it is defined as a group with a certain chain of subgroups.
The definition of a transposition involves the concept of a cycle, specifically a 2-cycle.
The definition of the kernel of a map involves the concept of a map (or function) and its domain, as it is defined as the set of elements in the domain that are mapped to zero.
